title: 106_hr4730
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia Recognition Act". The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia, descendants of the original Creek Indian Nation, are recognized as signatories of the 1832 Treaty of Washington. With over 2,500 eligible members, they chose not to be removed and continue to operate as a sovereign tribe in Georgia. The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia, descendants of the original Creek Indian Nation, chose not to be removed under the 1832 Treaty of Washington. Despite facing challenges in obtaining Federal recognition, the tribe continues its political and social existence with a viable tribal government. The government of Georgia and local governments have recognized the political leaders of the Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia as a distinct political entity. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "member" refers to an enrolled member of the Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia or an individual placed on the membership rolls in accordance with this Act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The term "Tribe" refers to the Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia. SEC. 4. FEDERAL RECOGNITION. Federal recognition is extended to the Tribe, making them eligible for all Federal benefits and services available to federally recognized Indian tribes. The Indian Reorganization Act of 1934 is applicable to the Tribe and its members. SEC. 5 of the Act establishes a reservation for the Tribe by allowing the Secretary to take land into trust for them within 2 years. Gaming on the trust land is prohibited. SEC. 6. BASE MEMBERSHIP ROLL.

The Tribe must submit a membership roll to the Secretary within 120 days of the Act's enactment, based on the Tribe's Constitution. Future membership is limited to lineal descendants of those on the base roll.

SEC. 7. JURISDICTION.

The reservation established by the Act falls under Federal and tribal jurisdiction.

SEC. 8. TREATIES NOT AFFECTED. SEC. 8. TREATIES NOT AFFECTED.

This Act does not amend, modify, or interpret any treaty involving tribes mentioned in the Act, preserving their rights secured by treaties.
